values.description:
Use /W4 instead of /Wall in MSVC , as /Wall in MSVC is full of totally unreasonable warnings. 

This is the solution already used in sdformat [1] and ign-math [2] . 

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/0dd38b0f34b3990057a1473aa857f730720d8a90/CMakeLists.txt?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-160

[2] : https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/945da32c0195cf8fc6ed872e8d2cc87aeb6bb585/CMakeLists.txt?fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-180

values.description:
This pull request replaces qt4 with qt5. Gazebo8 will only support qt5, and no version of gazebo will support both qt4 and qt5.

Changes include:

1. CMake switch from qt4 to qt5.
1. The renderFrame in GLWidget has been removed (not needed in qt5 - don't ask me why).
1. [Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33545006/qt5-attempt-to-set-a-screen-on-a-child-window-many-runtime-warning-messages). My solution is to capture the output in `GuiIface.cc` with a custom message handler.
1. MainWindow start size was problematic (xenial + gnome). The startup size would hide the X11 window frame. Reworked the `MainWindow::Init` function to account for this. 
1. Numerous qt api changes.

[Jenkins no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-no-gpu_ccache/34/console)

I'm working on the Windows side of things.

Please test this a lot.

Also please review [this release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/260) pull request, which jenkins requires.
values.title: Qt5

summary.raw:
This pull request replaces qt4 with qt5. Gazebo8 will only support qt5, and no version of gazebo will support both qt4 and qt5.

Changes include:

1. CMake switch from qt4 to qt5.
1. The renderFrame in GLWidget has been removed (not needed in qt5 - don't ask me why).
1. [Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33545006/qt5-attempt-to-set-a-screen-on-a-child-window-many-runtime-warning-messages). My solution is to capture the output in `GuiIface.cc` with a custom message handler.
1. MainWindow start size was problematic (xenial + gnome). The startup size would hide the X11 window frame. Reworked the `MainWindow::Init` function to account for this. 
1. Numerous qt api changes.

[Jenkins no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-no-gpu_ccache/34/console)

I'm working on the Windows side of things.

Please test this a lot.

Also please review [this release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/260) pull request, which jenkins requires.
summary.html:
This pull request replaces qt4 with qt5. Gazebo8 will only support qt5, and no version of gazebo will support both qt4 and qt5.

Changes include:

  1. CMake switch from qt4 to qt5.
  2. The renderFrame in GLWidget has been removed (not needed in qt5 - don't ask me why).
  3. Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings. My solution is to capture the output in GuiIface.cc with a custom message handler.
  4. MainWindow start size was problematic (xenial + gnome). The startup size would hide the X11 window frame. Reworked the MainWindow::Init function to account for this.
  5. Numerous qt api changes.

Jenkins no-gpu

I'm working on the Windows side of things.

Please test this a lot.

Also please review this release-tools pull request, which jenkins requires.

values.description:
The `InertiaVisual` class currently doesn't account for off-axis terms in inertia matrices. To demonstrate this, I've created `inertia_rotations.world`, which has 7 boxes of equivalent mass and world-frame moment of inertia matrix, though with different inertial frame rotations. Some of the inertial frame rotations are 90 degrees, so inertia values are swapped (for example `ixx` <=> `iyy`), while others have 45 degree rotations, so that there are non-zero off-diagonal terms. Here is a screenshot of the inertia visualization with gazebo 7.2.0. The 90-degree rotations are displayed properly, but the models with off-diagonal inertia values are shown incorrectly.

![Screen Shot 2016-06-21 at 10.17.51 AM.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/629613221-Screen_Shot_2016-06-21_at_10.17.51_AM.png)

The recent addition of the `MassMatrix3` class to `ignition-math2` make it straight-forward to account for the off-diagonal terms. This PR does the following:

* adds test world
* Require ignition-math2 2.4.0
* add helper functions for converting between `msgs::Inertial` and ignition math objects
* fixes `InertiaVisual` to account for off-diagonal inertia terms (see screenshot below)

![Screen Shot 2016-06-21 at 10.30.57 AM.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3233525410-Screen_Shot_2016-06-21_at_10.30.57_AM.png)

`InertiaVisual` doesn't have a test, but I will need some guidance on how to write this. Perhaps the test could use this example world?
values.title: Fix InertiaVisual for non-diagonal inertia matrices

summary.raw:
The `InertiaVisual` class currently doesn't account for off-axis terms in inertia matrices. To demonstrate this, I've created `inertia_rotations.world`, which has 7 boxes of equivalent mass and world-frame moment of inertia matrix, though with different inertial frame rotations. Some of the inertial frame rotations are 90 degrees, so inertia values are swapped (for example `ixx` <=> `iyy`), while others have 45 degree rotations, so that there are non-zero off-diagonal terms. Here is a screenshot of the inertia visualization with gazebo 7.2.0. The 90-degree rotations are displayed properly, but the models with off-diagonal inertia values are shown incorrectly.

![Screen Shot 2016-06-21 at 10.17.51 AM.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/629613221-Screen_Shot_2016-06-21_at_10.17.51_AM.png)

The recent addition of the `MassMatrix3` class to `ignition-math2` make it straight-forward to account for the off-diagonal terms. This PR does the following:

* adds test world
* Require ignition-math2 2.4.0
* add helper functions for converting between `msgs::Inertial` and ignition math objects
* fixes `InertiaVisual` to account for off-diagonal inertia terms (see screenshot below)

![Screen Shot 2016-06-21 at 10.30.57 AM.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3233525410-Screen_Shot_2016-06-21_at_10.30.57_AM.png)

`InertiaVisual` doesn't have a test, but I will need some guidance on how to write this. Perhaps the test could use this example world?
summary.html:
The InertiaVisual class currently doesn't account for off-axis terms in inertia matrices. To demonstrate this, I've created inertia_rotations.world, which has 7 boxes of equivalent mass and world-frame moment of inertia matrix, though with different inertial frame rotations. Some of the inertial frame rotations are 90 degrees, so inertia values are swapped (for example ixx <=> iyy), while others have 45 degree rotations, so that there are non-zero off-diagonal terms. Here is a screenshot of the inertia visualization with gazebo 7.2.0. The 90-degree rotations are displayed properly, but the models with off-diagonal inertia values are shown incorrectly.

The recent addition of the MassMatrix3 class to ignition-math2 make it straight-forward to account for the off-diagonal terms. This PR does the following:

  • adds test world
  • Require ignition-math2 2.4.0
  • add helper functions for converting between msgs::Inertial and ignition math objects
  • fixes InertiaVisual to account for off-diagonal inertia terms (see screenshot below)

InertiaVisual doesn't have a test, but I will need some guidance on how to write this. Perhaps the test could use this example world?

values.description: The `SignalStats` and `Vector3Stats` classes are in ignition math, so this deprecates the gazebo math versions of these classes.
values.title: Deprecate gazebo::math::SignalStats classes in favor of ignition math

summary.raw: The `SignalStats` and `Vector3Stats` classes are in ignition math, so this deprecates the gazebo math versions of these classes.
summary.html: The SignalStats and Vector3Stats classes are in ignition math, so this deprecates the gazebo math versions of these classes.

* tweaks to test and URI usage

* Close branch attach_plugins_louise

* implemented sensor properties + uniqueness with uris. Added test, fails.

values.description:
Two single character fixes to allow binary STL files to be loaded by gazebo on Windows.

In the current source a binary STL file can crash gzclient on Windows if the wrong value ends up in isspace. 

Without the "rb" parameter for the binary STL file open Windows will prematurely detect the end of the file and fail to load the STL.

Both these issues manifest with the GearBotDemo world.
values.title: Fix for binary STL file parsing on Windows

summary.raw:
Two single character fixes to allow binary STL files to be loaded by gazebo on Windows.

In the current source a binary STL file can crash gzclient on Windows if the wrong value ends up in isspace. 

Without the "rb" parameter for the binary STL file open Windows will prematurely detect the end of the file and fail to load the STL.

Both these issues manifest with the GearBotDemo world.

values.description:
L_INT16/32 images had been treated as MONO images. Since L_INT16/32 usually
represents luminance values, it's more reasonable to have them converted to
grayscale RGB before showing them on the topic viewer.

Also:

 - Treat each image type independently in a switch-case block.
 - Boolean isDepthImage is not necessary anymore, since depth images are
   converted inside a specific switch-case block.
 - Convert depthBuffer to std::Vector.
 - Store converted rgb into an rgb888Buffer vector before updating qImage.
 - Move lock_guard to reduce its scope around qImage only.
values.title: Treat L_INT16/32 as grayscale on ImgTopic viewer

summary.raw:
L_INT16/32 images had been treated as MONO images. Since L_INT16/32 usually
represents luminance values, it's more reasonable to have them converted to
grayscale RGB before showing them on the topic viewer.

Also:

 - Treat each image type independently in a switch-case block.
 - Boolean isDepthImage is not necessary anymore, since depth images are
   converted inside a specific switch-case block.
 - Convert depthBuffer to std::Vector.
 - Store converted rgb into an rgb888Buffer vector before updating qImage.
 - Move lock_guard to reduce its scope around qImage only.
summary.html:
L_INT16/32 images had been treated as MONO images. Since L_INT16/32 usually represents luminance values, it's more reasonable to have them converted to grayscale RGB before showing them on the topic viewer.

Also:

  • Treat each image type independently in a switch-case block.
  • Boolean isDepthImage is not necessary anymore, since depth images are converted inside a specific switch-case block.
  • Convert depthBuffer to std::Vector.
  • Store converted rgb into an rgb888Buffer vector before updating qImage.
  • Move lock_guard to reduce its scope around qImage only.

values.description:
* Requires [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/280/document-actor-make-skin-and-animation/diff) SDF pull request

* This PR should make [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/366/actor/diff) tutorial work

Changes:

* Use same skin and animation in `cafe.world`

* Made the shirt of `moonwalk.dae` red, so it is different from the other actors. This helps explaining the difference between skin and animation in the tutorial.

* Refactored `physics::Actor` so:

    * Scripts can be used without skin / animation (so it works if we have only links)

    * If animation is not specified, try to get animation from skin

* Added tests for actors
values.title: Generalize actors

values.description:
There is minor calculation error in vertices generation when connecting two road segments of different length. The bugfix is in f9488ed. 

I also updated the Road segments to create Ogre Meshes instead of SimpleRenderables and now they are able to receive shadows. ffebbd6

See screenshot below for before and after the fix.

![road_fix.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2136913570-road_fix.png)
	
A couple other changes:

- pimp'lize Road2d class and made Road2d inherit from Visual class.

-  Moved topic subscription and message processing logic to Scene. 

The changes let us attach more than one road visuals to the world and let the scene manage their life time.


jenkins:

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/520/) - ok
values.title: Fix Road2d vertices and shadows

summary.raw:
There is minor calculation error in vertices generation when connecting two road segments of different length. The bugfix is in f9488ed. 

I also updated the Road segments to create Ogre Meshes instead of SimpleRenderables and now they are able to receive shadows. ffebbd6

See screenshot below for before and after the fix.

![road_fix.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2136913570-road_fix.png)
	
A couple other changes:

- pimp'lize Road2d class and made Road2d inherit from Visual class.

-  Moved topic subscription and message processing logic to Scene. 

The changes let us attach more than one road visuals to the world and let the scene manage their life time.


jenkins:

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/520/) - ok
summary.html:
There is minor calculation error in vertices generation when connecting two road segments of different length. The bugfix is in f9488ed.

I also updated the Road segments to create Ogre Meshes instead of SimpleRenderables and now they are able to receive shadows. ffebbd6

See screenshot below for before and after the fix.

A couple other changes:

  • pimp'lize Road2d class and made Road2d inherit from Visual class.

  • Moved topic subscription and message processing logic to Scene.

The changes let us attach more than one road visuals to the world and let the scene manage their life time.

jenkins:

homebrew - ok

values.description: Per issue #1805, contact filters with names that include `::` are not removed properly. This includes a test that fails without the fix ([jenkins test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/60/testReport/junit/(root)/ContactManagerTest/RemoveFilter/)) and a fix.
values.title: Remove contact filters with names that contain :: (#1805)

summary.raw: Per issue #1805, contact filters with names that include `::` are not removed properly. This includes a test that fails without the fix ([jenkins test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/60/testReport/junit/(root)/ContactManagerTest/RemoveFilter/)) and a fix.
summary.html: Per issue #1805, contact filters with names that include :: are not removed properly. This includes a test that fails without the fix (jenkins test failure) and a fix.

values.description:
This pull request allows the `upload_doc.sh` script to target either the current version or dev.

Usage:


```
#!c++

sh upload_doc.sh [options]

Options:
    -d    Upload to development
```
values.title: Support uploading api documentation to dev target

values.description:
When associated to the RealSense model, this plugin publishes the 4 main streams of the RealSense camera (ir1, ir2, color and depth) in the same format as the real camera.

RealSense model pull request: [gazebo_models:204](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/204)
values.title: An Intel Real Sense R200 Camera plugin

summary.raw:

values.description:
In `test/integration/CMakeLists.txt` the `CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` definition is not in the same `if` block as the `model_editor_undo`. This could (and has) caused compilation to fail.

We should use `PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH`, which is already defined in `test_config.h`.
values.title: Fix compilation

summary.raw:
In `test/integration/CMakeLists.txt` the `CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` definition is not in the same `if` block as the `model_editor_undo`. This could (and has) caused compilation to fail.

We should use `PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH`, which is already defined in `test_config.h`.
summary.html:
In test/integration/CMakeLists.txt the CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR definition is not in the same if block as the model_editor_undo. This could (and has) caused compilation to fail.

We should use PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH, which is already defined in test_config.h.

values.description:
This removes our dependency on webkit. Instead of maintaining a html page in the gazebo sources, we will open a browser page to [http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys.html](http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys.html).

This pull request is also in the qt5 pull request. Please review this first and help make the qt5 pull request smaller.

There are downsides to this:

1. Internet connection is required
1. A person might not notice a new browser tab opening.

Those downsides are acceptable.
values.title: Remove hotkey

summary.raw:
This removes our dependency on webkit. Instead of maintaining a html page in the gazebo sources, we will open a browser page to [http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys.html](http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys.html).

This pull request is also in the qt5 pull request. Please review this first and help make the qt5 pull request smaller.

There are downsides to this:

1. Internet connection is required
1. A person might not notice a new browser tab opening.

Those downsides are acceptable.
summary.html:
This removes our dependency on webkit. Instead of maintaining a html page in the gazebo sources, we will open a browser page to http://gazebosim.org/hotkeys.html.

This pull request is also in the qt5 pull request. Please review this first and help make the qt5 pull request smaller.

There are downsides to this:

  1. Internet connection is required
  2. A person might not notice a new browser tab opening.

Those downsides are acceptable.

values.description:
The GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH and GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH variables are very useful for the installation of custom plugins. Currently only GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH is available through find_package(gazebo) on cmake. With this change, GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH is also made available, allowing custom models to be installed easily in the default model path with the following cmake command:

```
#!cmake
install(DIRECTORY my_models/ DESTINATION ${GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH})
```
values.title: Add GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH to config.cmake.in

summary.raw:
The GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH and GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH variables are very useful for the installation of custom plugins. Currently only GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH is available through find_package(gazebo) on cmake. With this change, GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH is also made available, allowing custom models to be installed easily in the default model path with the following cmake command:

```
#!cmake
install(DIRECTORY my_models/ DESTINATION ${GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH})
```
summary.html:
The GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH and GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH variables are very useful for the installation of custom plugins. Currently only GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH is available through find_package(gazebo) on cmake. With this change, GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH is also made available, allowing custom models to be installed easily in the default model path with the following cmake command:

install(DIRECTORY my_models/ DESTINATION ${GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH})

values.description:
With QT5 [Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33545006/qt5-attempt-to-set-a-screen-on-a-child-window-many-runtime-warning-messages). 

This pull request captures the output in `GuiIface.cc` with a custom message handler.

This pull request is target to gazebo7, even though qt5 will only be in gazebo8 and above. I believe this feature is useful when/if other QT issues arise.
values.title: Use qt message handler

summary.raw:
With QT5 [Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33545006/qt5-attempt-to-set-a-screen-on-a-child-window-many-runtime-warning-messages). 

This pull request captures the output in `GuiIface.cc` with a custom message handler.

This pull request is target to gazebo7, even though qt5 will only be in gazebo8 and above. I believe this feature is useful when/if other QT issues arise.
summary.html:
With QT5 Dual monitors cause Qt to spam the console with warnings.

This pull request captures the output in GuiIface.cc with a custom message handler.

This pull request is target to gazebo7, even though qt5 will only be in gazebo8 and above. I believe this feature is useful when/if other QT issues arise.

values.description:
This pull request breaks out a few miscellaneous changes in pull request #2353.

1. Rearrange `GLWidget::OnMouseMove` so that the more common use cases it fewer `if` statements.
1. nullptr
1. Use `std::thread` in place of boost
1. pragma statements to prevent warning messages.
1. Change `children` to `mychildren` because `WallSegmentItem` will have an inherited `children` member variable.
values.title: Parts of pull request #2353

summary.raw:
This pull request breaks out a few miscellaneous changes in pull request #2353.

1. Rearrange `GLWidget::OnMouseMove` so that the more common use cases it fewer `if` statements.
1. nullptr
1. Use `std::thread` in place of boost
1. pragma statements to prevent warning messages.
1. Change `children` to `mychildren` because `WallSegmentItem` will have an inherited `children` member variable.
summary.html:
This pull request breaks out a few miscellaneous changes in pull request #2353.

  1. Rearrange GLWidget::OnMouseMove so that the more common use cases it fewer if statements.
  2. nullptr
  3. Use std::thread in place of boost
  4. pragma statements to prevent warning messages.
  5. Change children to mychildren because WallSegmentItem will have an inherited children member variable.

values.description: This replaces instances of `gazebo::math` classes with `ignition::math` classes in msgs.cc and msgs_TEST.cc and also causes `gazebo_msgs` to not link against `gazebo_math`. There are still `gazebo/math` headers in `msgs.hh`, but these will be removed on default, rather than on gazebo7.
values.title: Use ignition math in gazebo::msgs

summary.raw: This replaces instances of `gazebo::math` classes with `ignition::math` classes in msgs.cc and msgs_TEST.cc and also causes `gazebo_msgs` to not link against `gazebo_math`. There are still `gazebo/math` headers in `msgs.hh`, but these will be removed on default, rather than on gazebo7.
summary.html: This replaces instances of gazebo::math classes with ignition::math classes in msgs.cc and msgs_TEST.cc and also causes gazebo_msgs to not link against gazebo_math. There are still gazebo/math headers in msgs.hh, but these will be removed on default, rather than on gazebo7.

values.description:
When creating a rigid body in bullet, only diagonal inertia terms are accepted for the moment of inertia matrix in the body-fixed frame (`btRigidBodyConstructionInfo::m_localInertia` [is a btVector3](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/src/BulletDynamics/Dynamics/btRigidBody.h#L129)). As such, we have been ignoring off-diagonal terms in the moment of inertia matrix. With the recent additions to `ignition::math::MassMatrix3`, it is now straight-forward to diagonalize the inertia matrices to properly express these matrices in bullet. A [failing test case](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/103/testReport/junit/(root)/PhysicsEngines_PhysicsLinkTest/GetWorldInertia_1/) was added in 5ad26bcd3fec and fixed in f00c768, 6ef5d85.

I've also included some small related fixes and re-factoring:

* Add helper functions for converting from `gazebo::physics::Inertial` to `ignition::math::Inertiald`

* f34c168: Fix triangle inequality expectation to >= instead of >

* Use new ignition::math `SetFromGeometry` helper functions in msgs.cc and ModelData.cc to de-duplicate some inertia computation code

cc @erwincoumans in case you've wondered about supporting off-diagonal inertia terms expressed in URDF
values.title: Support off-diagonal inertia terms in bullet

summary.raw:
When creating a rigid body in bullet, only diagonal inertia terms are accepted for the moment of inertia matrix in the body-fixed frame (`btRigidBodyConstructionInfo::m_localInertia` [is a btVector3](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/src/BulletDynamics/Dynamics/btRigidBody.h#L129)). As such, we have been ignoring off-diagonal terms in the moment of inertia matrix. With the recent additions to `ignition::math::MassMatrix3`, it is now straight-forward to diagonalize the inertia matrices to properly express these matrices in bullet. A [failing test case](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/103/testReport/junit/(root)/PhysicsEngines_PhysicsLinkTest/GetWorldInertia_1/) was added in 5ad26bcd3fec and fixed in f00c768, 6ef5d85.

I've also included some small related fixes and re-factoring:

* Add helper functions for converting from `gazebo::physics::Inertial` to `ignition::math::Inertiald`

* f34c168: Fix triangle inequality expectation to >= instead of >

* Use new ignition::math `SetFromGeometry` helper functions in msgs.cc and ModelData.cc to de-duplicate some inertia computation code

cc @erwincoumans in case you've wondered about supporting off-diagonal inertia terms expressed in URDF
summary.html:
When creating a rigid body in bullet, only diagonal inertia terms are accepted for the moment of inertia matrix in the body-fixed frame (btRigidBodyConstructionInfo::m_localInertia is a btVector3). As such, we have been ignoring off-diagonal terms in the moment of inertia matrix. With the recent additions to ignition::math::MassMatrix3, it is now straight-forward to diagonalize the inertia matrices to properly express these matrices in bullet. A failing test case was added in 5ad26bcd3fec and fixed in f00c768, 6ef5d85.

I've also included some small related fixes and re-factoring:

  • Add helper functions for converting from gazebo::physics::Inertial to ignition::math::Inertiald

  • f34c168: Fix triangle inequality expectation to >= instead of >

  • Use new ignition::math SetFromGeometry helper functions in msgs.cc and ModelData.cc to de-duplicate some inertia computation code

cc @erwincoumans in case you've wondered about supporting off-diagonal inertia terms expressed in URDF

values.description:
Version 4.0 of tinyxml2 has just been released and is being used in homebrew. There is a small API change that causes gazebo7+ builds to fail (gazebo6 and earlier don't use tinyxml2). For some reason, there were two separate enums used to return success of an API call: `XML_NO_ERROR` and `XML_SUCCESS`. `XML_NO_ERROR` was [added first on Feb 21, 2012](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/68db57e#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bR576), though `XML_SUCCESS` was [added shortly after on Feb 27, 2012](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/7d00b9ab#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bR717). Both enums are present in the `libtinyxml2-dev` [package on trusty](http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/libtinyxml2-dev), which is based on the version from May 2012.

The `XML_NO_ERROR` enum was [removed recently on June 4, 2016](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/8553625#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bL488) and included in the 4.0.0 release. It should be fine to switch to using `XML_SUCCESS`, since that is available in the version on trusty.
values.title: Use XML_SUCCESS enum instead of XML_NO_ERROR, which has been deleted in tinyxml2 4.0

summary.raw:
Version 4.0 of tinyxml2 has just been released and is being used in homebrew. There is a small API change that causes gazebo7+ builds to fail (gazebo6 and earlier don't use tinyxml2). For some reason, there were two separate enums used to return success of an API call: `XML_NO_ERROR` and `XML_SUCCESS`. `XML_NO_ERROR` was [added first on Feb 21, 2012](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/68db57e#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bR576), though `XML_SUCCESS` was [added shortly after on Feb 27, 2012](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/7d00b9ab#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bR717). Both enums are present in the `libtinyxml2-dev` [package on trusty](http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/libtinyxml2-dev), which is based on the version from May 2012.

The `XML_NO_ERROR` enum was [removed recently on June 4, 2016](https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/commit/8553625#diff-f0c986b0c387a2c34d4d6232c8d8c86bL488) and included in the 4.0.0 release. It should be fine to switch to using `XML_SUCCESS`, since that is available in the version on trusty.
summary.html:
Version 4.0 of tinyxml2 has just been released and is being used in homebrew. There is a small API change that causes gazebo7+ builds to fail (gazebo6 and earlier don't use tinyxml2). For some reason, there were two separate enums used to return success of an API call: XML_NO_ERROR and XML_SUCCESS. XML_NO_ERROR was added first on Feb 21, 2012, though XML_SUCCESS was added shortly after on Feb 27, 2012. Both enums are present in the libtinyxml2-dev package on trusty, which is based on the version from May 2012.

The XML_NO_ERROR enum was removed recently on June 4, 2016 and included in the 4.0.0 release. It should be fine to switch to using XML_SUCCESS, since that is available in the version on trusty.

values.title: Add copy accessors to uri path and query

summary.html:
I needed these when trying to pass a URI as a const parameter into a function and use the Path and Query accessors inside it, for example:

ModelPtr ModelFromURI(const common::URI &_uri)
{
  ...
  // The following is not alowed without this PR
  auto pathStr = _uri.Path().Str();
}

Please let me know if t
